vdf:field.vdf:value: What happens to the refugees on Manus Island?

vdf:field.name: description
vdf:field.vdf:value: Australia’s detention centre in Papua New Guinea has closed, leaving detainees in limbo

p.style: color: rgb(18, 18, 18); font-family: MiloSerifPro, Palatino, serif; font-size: 20px;

div.p: ABOUT 600 asylum-seekers barricaded themselves inside a detention centre on Manus Island, in Papua New Guinea (PNG), after it closed on October 31st. Australia’s government, which put them there in the first place, had hoped that they would have returned home or else been resettled. Since this has not happened, it has decided that those who remain in PNG should move either to a transit centre (which is less closely guarded than the detention centre) or to accommodation in a nearby town. But the men—and they are all men—fear for their safety if they do so. Many local people resent the refugees, some of whom have been attacked with knives, sticks and screwdrivers while police look the other way. Local authorities have switched off electricity and water supplies at the barricaded detention centre, leaving the asylum-seekers to survive on stockpiles of food and rainwater. On November 7th PNG’s supreme court rejected a bid by lawyers for Behrouz Boochani, a Kurdish-Iranian detainee, to keep the centre open. PNG’s armed forces may now push them out.

p.style: color: rgb(18, 18, 18); font-family: MiloSerifPro, Palatino, serif; font-size: 20px;

div.p: Since first attempting to reach Australia, many of the men have languished on the island for over four years. Their plight is the legacy of a policy dubbed the “Pacific solution”. This was started by John Howard, a conservative prime minister, in 2001 when he turned away a cargo ship that had rescued 433 asylum-seekers from a sinking boat. His government was allowed to open camps on Manus and Nauru, another Pacific island, in return for economic aid. The plan was for asylum-seekers to stay there while they were screened. A centre-left Labor government later closed the units, but reopened them in 2012. Governments of both stripes have since pursued ever-harsher policies aimed to deter “boat people”. Most of the 1,000-odd asylum-seekers left on the islands are refugees from war-afflicted regions. Yet, as a utilitarian lesson to others, Australia refuses to grant them residency. Since 2012 its “Pacific solution” had cost taxpayers close to A$5bn ($3.8bn). Nationalists in Europe hold up the policy as an example. The United Nations, on the other hand, has repeatedly condemned it for breaching international laws on human rights. And PNG’s supreme court asked Australia to close the Manus Island centre after ruling it to be “unconstitutional and illegal”.
